Centuries of Wisdom

About Tai Chi

Explore the origins, philosophy, and practice of Tai Chi, and experience this treasure of Chinese culture

Centuries

of Heritage

Origins

Historical Origins

Tai Chi Chuan originated in China during the Ming Dynasty, created by Zhang Sanfeng of the Wudang sect. It integrates Taoist philosophy, traditional medicine, and martial arts essence, serving as an important component of Chinese traditional culture.

Named after "Tai Chi" (Supreme Ultimate), it draws from the philosophical concept in the "Book of Changes": "Tai Chi generates the Two Powers (Yin and Yang), the Two Powers generate the Four Images, and the Four Images generate the Eight Trigrams." It emphasizes Yin-Yang balance, the interplay of hardness and softness, pursuing harmony between humanity and nature.

After centuries of inheritance and development, Tai Chi has formed multiple schools including Chen, Yang, Wu, Wu (Hao), and Sun. Each school has its unique style and characteristics, yet all follow the same core philosophy.

üìú Ming Dynasty Origins ‚õ∞Ô∏è Wudang Heritage üåø Taoist Philosophy
Core Philosophy

Tai Chi Principles

Harmony of Yin and Yang, Movement and Stillness, Hardness and Softness

‚òØÔ∏è

Yin-Yang Balance

The core of Tai Chi is Yin-Yang balance. Through Yin-Yang transitions in movement, achieve harmony of body and mind.

‚ö°

Movement and Stillness

Movement within stillness, stillness within movement. Tai Chi emphasizes continuous movement and inner tranquility.

üí™

Hardness and Softness

Hardness with softness, softness with hardness. The interplay of hard and soft is a key characteristic of Tai Chi movements.

üßò

Mind and Breath Unity

Mind leads breath, breath moves body. Perfect coordination of intention, breath, and movement.

Key Features

Tai Chi Characteristics

1

Slow and Smooth

Movements are slow, continuous, and circular, like flowing clouds and water, uninterrupted

2

Natural Breathing

Coordinated with movement, using abdominal breathing to achieve internal and external cultivation

3

Mind Calm, Body Relaxed

Focus mind, relax body, internal concentration, eliminate distracting thoughts

4

Whole Body Coordination

Upper and lower body follow each other, left and right connected, internal and external unity, whole body coordination

Modern Value

Tai Chi and Modern Life

In today's fast-paced modern life, Tai Chi is increasingly loved and valued for its unique fitness and health benefits.

Scientific research confirms that long-term Tai Chi practice can improve cardiopulmonary function, enhance immunity, relieve stress and anxiety, improve sleep quality, and delay aging.

Tai Chi is not just an exercise, but a lifestyle. It teaches us to maintain inner tranquility amidst busyness and balanced minds amidst change.

Physical Fitness
Mind Cultivation
Anti-Aging
Stress Relief

Global Spread

Cultural treasure across five continents

Five Major Schools

Tai Chi Schools

Unique characteristics, shared lineage

üéã

Chen Style

Original School

Created by Chen Wangting in late Ming and early Qing Dynasty, the earliest Tai Chi school. Movements combine hardness and softness, alternate fast and slow, include explosive power and jumps.

Features: Silk-reeling energy, explosive power, clear distinction between emptiness and fullness

üåä

Yang Style

Most Widespread

Adapted by Yang Luchan from Chen Style. Movements are expansive and graceful, even tempo, beautiful postures.

Features: Soft and slow, circular and full, natural and elegant

üé≠

Wu Style

Compact and Refined

Developed by Wu Jianquan from Yang Style. Movements are compact and refined, emphasizing softness, delicate and precise.

Features: Compact and soft, upright within angles, delicate and continuous

‚öîÔ∏è

Wu (Hao) Style

Internal Focus

Created by Wu Yuxiang, emphasizing internal cultivation. Movements are compact, focused on body method, emphasizing "mind leads breath."

Features: Internal focus, strict body method, clear distinction of emptiness and fullness

üèÉ

Sun Style

Opening and Closing

Created by Sun Lutang, integrating Xingyiquan and Baguazhang. Movements are flexible and varied, advance and retreat together, expansive and circular.

Features: Opening and closing combined, flexible and varied, agile footwork

‚òØÔ∏è

He Style

Traditional

Created by He Zhaoyuan, preserving many traditional features. Movements are simple and unadorned, practical and effective.

Features: Traditional and simple, practical, strong combat application

Classic Forms

Tai Chi Forms

From simple to complex, step-by-step progression

Beginner's Choice

24-Form Tai Chi

Simplified Tai Chi

24

movements

Compiled in 1956 by the National Sports Commission, selecting 24 movements from Yang Style. Movements are standardized, structure is reasonable, easy to learn and practice, the best choice for Tai Chi beginners.

5-6 minutes
Beginner friendly
Expansive movements
Nationally promoted
Competition Standard

42-Form Tai Chi

Comprehensive Competition Form

42

movements

Integrating characteristics of Chen, Yang, Wu, and Sun styles, scientifically arranged with high technical content, the standard competition form for various Tai Chi competitions.

6-7 minutes
Requires foundation
Multi-style fusion
Competition form
Advanced Level

48-Form Tai Chi

Yang Style Advanced Form

48

movements

Created based on Yang Style, rich in content and comprehensive in technique, preserving traditional characteristics while incorporating innovation, suitable for practitioners with foundation.

7-8 minutes
Advanced practice
Yang Style
More comprehensive
Traditional Heritage

Traditional 108 Form

Complete Traditional Form

108

movements

The complete traditional Yang Style form, comprehensive in movements and rich in content, containing the core philosophy and techniques of Tai Chi, the classic choice for deep Tai Chi study.

20-25 minutes
Long-term practice
Traditional Yang
Richest content
Health and Wellness

Health Benefits

Scientifically validated, significant results

‚ù§Ô∏è

Improves Cardiopulmonary Function

Tai Chi's aerobic exercise nature enhances cardiopulmonary endurance, improves blood circulation efficiency, and reduces cardiovascular disease risk.

Strengthens myocardial contraction
Increases lung capacity
Promotes blood circulation
‚öñÔ∏è

Enhances Balance

Tai Chi's slow movements and weight shift training significantly improve body balance and stability, especially suitable for middle-aged and elderly people.

Improves body stability
Reduces fall risk
Enhances gait coordination
üí™

Increases Muscle Strength

Although movements are slow, Tai Chi requires continuous muscle control, effectively strengthening lower limb strength and core stability.

Strengthens lower limbs
Improves core stability
Increases joint flexibility
üßò

Relieves Stress and Anxiety

Tai Chi combines meditation and movement, effectively lowering stress hormone levels, relieving anxiety and depression, enhancing mental health.

Lowers cortisol levels
Improves mental state
Enhances sleep quality

Long-term Tai Chi practice strengthens immune system function, improves body resistance, and reduces disease occurrence.

Enhances immune cell activity
Increases disease resistance

Delays osteoporosis

Practice Guide

Practice Essentials

Master the correct method, achieve twice the result with half the effort

I

Upright Posture

Keep the body naturally upright, head straight, neck relaxed, spine naturally extended. All body parts coordinated, centered, like a bell hanging.

II

Clear Distinction of Emptiness and Fullness

Clearly distinguish emptiness and fullness in the body, weight transfer should be clear. Separate emptiness and fullness in both feet, proper weight distribution, natural and smooth transitions.

III

Mind and Breath Together

Mind leads breath, breath moves body. Mind as the guide, breath coordinates with movement, where mind goes, breath goes, where breath goes, strength goes. Unity of internal and external, form and spirit.

IV

Continuous and Circular

Movements should be continuous and circular, like flowing clouds and water, uninterrupted. Natural transitions between movements, no pauses or breaks, whole body coordination, upper and lower body following each other.

Practice Recommendations

üìÖ

Practice Frequency

Recommend practicing 3-5 times per week, 30-60 minutes each session. Long-term consistent practice yields better results. Beginners can start with 15-20 minutes per session.

‚è∞

Best Time

Early morning 5-7 AM or evening 4-6 PM is optimal, when air is fresh and body condition is good. Avoid practicing immediately after meals.

üå≥

Practice Location

Choose locations with fresh air and quiet environment. Parks, courtyards, lakesides are all suitable. Ground should be level, avoid surfaces that are too hard or too soft.

‚ö†Ô∏è

Precautions

  • ‚Ä¢ Wear loose, comfortable exercise clothing
  • ‚Ä¢ Warm up properly before practice
  • ‚Ä¢ Practice according to your ability, progress gradually
  • ‚Ä¢ Movements should be gentle, avoid excessive force
  • ‚Ä¢ Stop immediately if you feel discomfort
